articles.headline: Boris N. Yeltsin, Reformer Who Broke Up the U.S.S.R., Dies at 76
articles.snippet: Boris N. Yeltsin, Russia’s first freely elected leader, presided over the end of the Soviet Union and the Communist Party.
articles.abstract: Boris N. Yeltsin, Russia’s first freely elected leader, presided over the end of the Soviet Union and the Communist Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boris N. Yeltsin, the burly provincial politician who became a Soviet-era reformer and later a towering figure of his time as the first freely elected leader of Russia, presiding over the dissolution of the Soviet Union and the demise of the Communist Party, died yesterday in Moscow. He was 76.

articles.headline: Rival Offer Could Derail ABN Merger
articles.snippet: The deal with Barclays reduces, but does not eliminate, the chance of another suitor coming in with a higher bid.
articles.abstract: The deal with Barclays reduces, but does not eliminate, the chance of another suitor coming in with a higher bid.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, April 23 — ABN Amro agreed Monday to be acquired by Barclays of Britain for 67 billion euros (nearly $91 billion), creating one of the world’s largest banks in a carefully constructed deal that reduces, but does not eliminate, the chance of another suitor coming in with a higher bid to buy and break up the bank.

articles.headline: In Las Vegas, Too Many Hotels Are Never Enough
articles.snippet: The current construction craze along the Las Vegas Strip is driven by a 95 percent weekend occupancy rate.
articles.abstract: The current construction craze along the Las Vegas Strip is driven by a 95 percent weekend occupancy rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Stephen A. Wynn, the hotel and gambling impresario, still remembers the first time he was asked if he and other developers had lost their minds building so many casino hotels here. It was the mid-1970s, when Las Vegas had about 35,000 rooms.

articles.headline: China Yields to Inquiry on Pet Food
articles.snippet: China has given U.S. regulators permission to investigate whether suppliers exported contaminated pet food ingredients to the U.S.
articles.abstract: China has given U.S. regulators permission to investigate whether suppliers exported contaminated pet food ingredients to the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING, April 23 — China on Monday has given American regulators permission to enter the country to investigate whether Chinese suppliers exported contaminated pet food ingredients to the United States earlier this year, leading to one of the largest pet food recalls in American history.

articles.headline: Line Up and Pick a Dragon: Bhutan Learns to Vote
articles.snippet: Voters in the tiny Buddhist nation chose among “dummy” parties in a rehearsal for multiparty elections next year.
articles.abstract: Voters in the tiny Buddhist nation chose among “dummy” parties in a rehearsal for multiparty elections next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: THIMPHU, Bhutan, April 22 — Can “Desperate Housewives,” free trade and multiparty elections deliver happiness?

articles.headline: Ex-Officers of Apple Await Suit
articles.snippet: Two former executives expect to be sued this week by the S.E.C. over the company’s backdating of employee stock options.
articles.abstract: Two former executives expect to be sued this week by the S.E.C. over the company’s backdating of employee stock options.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two former Apple executives expect to be sued this week by the Securities and Exchange Commission over the company’s backdating of employee stock options, several people involved in negotiations between the former executives and the government said yesterday.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and Eric Dash

articles.headline: A Difficult Annual Times Meeting for Sulzbergers
articles.snippet: With The New York Times Company’s stock performance lagging, the Sulzberger family is bracing for a contentious meeting today.
articles.abstract: With The New York Times Company’s stock performance lagging, the Sulzberger family is bracing for a contentious meeting today.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company annual shareholder meeting traditionally has been a tame affair, where the Sulzberger family, which owns a controlling interest in the company, applauds the achievements of its journalists and, in turn, basks in the applause of investors.

articles.headline: Top Hedge Fund Managers Earn Over $240 Million
articles.snippet: A ranking of the top 25 earners shows that for the hedge fund elite, the rich are getting much richer in a hurry.
articles.abstract: A ranking of the top 25 earners shows that for the hedge fund elite, the rich are getting much richer in a hurry.
articles.lead_paragraph: James Simons, a 69-year-old publicity shy former math professor, uses complex computer-driven mathematical models to make bets on stocks, bonds and commodities, among other things.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Obama’s Rise Strains Loyalty on Clinton Turf
articles.snippet: A number of New York’s black elected officials say they are undecided in the Democratic presidential race.
articles.abstract: A number of New York’s black elected officials say they are undecided in the Democratic presidential race.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only a few months ago, the vast majority of black elected officials in New York were expected to support the presidential candidacy of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. But no longer.
